/btg/ BOOT GENERAL - BULLHIDE EDITION

What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4/renovateur
>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

>Should I buy turdsdays/soloshits/doc shitans?
No they are filled with synthetic materials aimed at instant comfort but will not hold up to actual use.
>b-b-but muh ecelebs on youtube said they're good
no. you will waste your time and money and still have uncomfortable footwear at the end of the day. spend the extra $100 and get something real.

Manufacturer Red Flags
>Luxury
>Sustainable
>Vegan
>Unknown leather source

You're a stupid bitch and dumb asses like you ruin entire fucking industries.

You can get an amazing MTO boot for $250-700, brand new. Let's go for the max price here, $700. Avoid the prestige trap money pit "big names", do 30 mins of research.

Let's assume the average reader is 25 years old and will die at 80. And let's say they have to resole the boot three times at $150 each over the course of their life. So one pair of boots, life time cost is $1150. Over 55 years that's $21/yr for one pair of boots.

Now let's say he gets a cheap pair of boots for $100, and they last three years. They won't, but let's pretend. That works out to $33.34/yr, for shitty boots.

I know you're literally too stupid to comprehend this but for anyone else with two fucking brain cells it's always cheaper long term to get the better product. And this is a best case scenario for the shit product, it costs more per year if it doesn't last as long. Latest shitter for my Tissot collection. This one was made by fucking Casio of all companies, and sold under license with Tissot's branding on the "dial", inner caseback, and on the bracelet. Other than that? It's a regular Casio Casiotron from the 70's. Super weird shit.

>>17471572
That stepper motor is properly fucking retarded. I've seen these before in like early Ronda movements.

It's especially embarrassing for the Swiss, that the Japanese already had proper stepper motors figured out already in the beginning. Pic related is my Seiko 3803, the 38xx series was Seiko's very first actual mass-production quartz movements. You can't go any further back in time than that without shelling out ridiculous money for a Seiko quartz that was made only in like 10000 units, or 1000, or a 100 (yeah, Seiko had production runs like that for their first quartz movements). But already you have the now-common motor layout.

Also I wonder if that Tissot has a Motorola chip. In the early days watch manufacturers didn't have chip manufacturing set up yet, so they bought the frequency-divider chips from companies like Motorola.

Also getting a vintage high beat that doesn't break the bank is getting tricky by now. If you settle for 28800bph you can look into Seiko Elnix electrics, or Citizen Leopards. >That stepper motor is properly fucking retarded. [...]
Tell me about it, I fucking love how backwards Tissot 2030 and 2031 movements are, though. They're such weird little turds, but I'm slightly in love with them for that fact. I got mega lucky with the one in the pic above as this is what it looked like before I serviced it. Delicious battery corrosion. Didn't even need any parts replacing which is absolutely mental given how far gone it was.
>It's especially embarrassing for the Swiss, that the Japanese already had proper stepper motors figured out already in the beginning. [...]
This is pretty common of Japanese watches in general, I find. They BTFO the Swiss at every corner, and usually do it for a fraction of the price in the process. I know those Seiko Quartz-Astrons or whatever they were called bring fucking mad money, but it's not surprising when there are so few of them to go around. I rarely buy Japanese watches, but the Seiko Quartz Superior Morpho will forever be at the very top of my "grail" list. It's immensely beautiful.
>Also I wonder if that Tissot has a Motorola chip. In the early days watch manufacturers didn't have chip manufacturing set up yet, so they bought the frequency-divider chips from companies like Motorola.
I have no clue, unfortunately. You might be able to find out on CrazyWatches.pl if you're keen on finding out, though.
>I'm not sure if it's gonna die at all, unless you have a chink alkaline battery leaking, or water ingress, those movements are mostly metal.
I use silver-oxide batteries in all of my shitters, I've seen enough disasters like picrel to know better than that. The movement in my Mondaine already has issues, which is why I am incredibly wary of it. That, and the setting feels a bit crunchy sometimes. I might have a go at servicing it sooner or later, just never worked on one before and can't find enough documentation about how to work on them. Got any resources?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17472177
I'm a big fan of Japanese watches, especially Orient and Seiko. But i wouldn't recommend a Bambino if you're willing to fork out 700-800 for a dressy watch.
With that kind of money you can get a dressy, but still somewhat casual Certina or Tissot model (leather strap, or bracelet). I like the Visodate, but you can go for one without the day of the week indicator, lots of models, so i encourage you to browse those two brands in particular.
There's any Hamilton Jazzmaster (tho i don't like them personally).

But if you're looking to go cheaper i think it boils down to Bambino vs Cocktail time.
Both are beautiful, the Seikos have an edge, but they are more expensive. It boils down to "do i need this 100-150$ , should i use it for something else, save it, or buy another watch". If the answer is "yes, yes, i could use that money for something else", then get the bambino you like the most. If you're willing to dish it out for one watch, get the cocktail time.
I find most models of both lines beautiful, but SRPH78J1 is a fucking stunner. It looks like it could easily cost 4-5 times more, and it's like 10$ more retail than the basic cocktail time (if your retailer has it, that is).
Or check out some Orient star models.
But 1000$ gives you a lot more options. The bambino is a no brainer if you have 500$ sitting around, and could maybe use some of that money next month.

>>17472715
DHT is the main cause of hairloss because it's toxic to hair follicles. Generally your DHT increases when your T increases, but DHT levels still vary strongly from person to person. DHT sensitivity of the follicles in the scalp also varies from person to person.
So high T people are probably more likely to go bald, but that doesn't mean that all (or most) high T people go bald, or that people who are bald are high T, or that people who are low T don't go bald.

That's what I picked up from lurking mostly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Demeter fragrances blind buy.
2 keepers, 2 for birthday gifts, and 5 that won't be used much - if at all. Will not be buying any of these again. I sampled these all last night. Took a long shower afterwards. My nose was burning and I had a headache.
Listed from best to worst:

>Amber
sweet and spicy, creamy, earthy, warm.
vanilla, dry woods, incense, spices, some very light citrus - i think its orange

>Pineapple
pineapple juice. sweet and syrupy
its really strong.

>Cedar
old dusty cedar boards. something lemony and bitter, a little earthy

>Hawaiian Vanilla
sweet vanilla with a hint of coconut
suntan lotion or a 'tropical' scented body cream

>Pipe Tobacco
sweet and spicy, woody, smokey. its definitely pipe tobacco. becomes dryer and ashier over time
theres a very faint metallic cherry scent that you get with almond extract

>Pistachio Ice Cream
pistachio ice cream, pistachio pudding, pistachio cookies

>Sandalwood
sweet, soapy, powdery sandalwood
smells like an air freshener

>Pink Grapefruit
bitter grapefruit peels, soapy, medicinal
'citrus' scented cleaning solution

>Russian Leather
dirty leather couch, old books, and an ash tray

You're an actual confused retard. Rick Owens has ALWAYS made super basic super wearable shit and that has always been his bread and butter and where he makes most of his money. Pic related is some of what Mr. Porter is selling from Rick right now. The problem is you cannot do a runway show comprised entirely of plain basic stuff like this. People would get bored and sick of it ASAP. When people go to a runway show they don't want to see the basic ass clothes that end up in the stores and that they know will end up on their backs.

The whole point of the runway show is the designer putting together the craziest fits possible on the hottest people possible with unlimited money. The idea is you get to see the craziest and most undiluted version of the designers vision. It's supposed to get you excited and hyped to then go buy the basic ass plain blank tank top from Mr. Porter. This is how the entire fashion industry has operated forever. This isn't some new trend you've just recognized you complete and utter moron. It's the status quo from before you were even born.

Fashion HAS ALWAYS AND WILL ALWAYS be about "wearable clothes that look good" as you put it because that's what actually sells. The runway is a fantasy it's not what stores buy it's not what people buy outside a handful of outliers.

>>17434337
This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

posts.com:
The more you get into something the more esoteric and abstract your taste becomes. Especially if you're hanging out with other people who are equally into that thing. All those people are going to be trying to one up and impress each other. It doesn't remotely make any sense that they would be wearing really basic and palatable stuff that the general public is into.

This happens with literally every single field on Earth its not strange or weird at all. It applies to everything from fashion to even the lamest most boring and corny shit I can think of like board games.

If you hang out with a bunch of people really into board games they're not going to be playing Monopoly. They're going to be busting out really weird discontinued board games with complicated and bizarre rules. Imagine going up to those people and telling them they should be playing Monopoly because that's what everyone likes. Nigga these mfers done finished with Monopoly now it's time for Twilight Imperium: Third Edition.

People deeply into fashion or anything else are exactly the same. They don't give a fuck what the general public is into.

Because pic related is the alternative. That's what happens when everyone tries to look as good as possible to as many people as possible. If you're really into this shit you don't care about looking good to NPC's. You're going to experiment and wear weird ass silhouettes and stuff that's objectively ugly to see if you can find some weird way to make it work. That's where all the fun and interest is. It's in the weird fucked up concepts and the stuff that's rough around the edges and has soul. Those are the things that are way more interesting to discuss and pursue. NOT trying to look good to as many people as possible. That's a solved equation and it's boring as shit. It's something for NPC's to concern themselves with.

Like I said this applies to all creative fields. You ask a professional artist what type of stuff inspires them they're not going to say the Mona Lisa lol they're probably going to say something weird and fucked up and objectively "shit" like Chris-Chans art or Tails Gets Trolled.

posts.sub: Is it just me or are women who show more skin often more warm/friendly than women who cover up more?
posts.com:
By "show more skin" I mean stuff like tank tops and short shorts, and by "cover up more" I mean stuff like long sleeves and long pants/jeans. As you can see in the attached photos.
I don't know why, but to me it just seems like women who show more skin are often more warm/friendly than women who cover up more. I often associate the former with smiling more often, generally hugging more and being more touchy feely, and displaying overall more extroverted and outgoing traits... and the latter more with smiling less, disliking hugs and physical contact, and displaying overall more introverted and reserved traits.
Another thing, women who show skin seem to not care when another woman decides to cover up... at most they'll ask them "aren't you feeling hot" if the temperature is high, but they'll leave it at that. However, women who cover up often seem to be quite judgmental of women who show more skin, and seem to think that they are morally superior to them. They seem to think women who show more skin are "dressing wrong" or "being slutty."
I'm not sure if this is just me/a coincidence, or if it's actually a common pattern that exists in a lot of places. Which is why I'm asking.
If it matters, I myself would usually dress something in-between the two photos. Like a t-shirt and shorts that are closer to knee-length. Though I occasionally may adopt the style shown in the photos as well, depending on the weather.

>>17469849
Here's what I found prolongs the life of my jeans.
-wash once every 6 months or per year. I have a bunch of them and rotate a lot. But if yours get really dirty you might want to wash mote often.
-Use non-abrassive detergent. For this purpose I use my country's equivalent of tide pods. Powder detergent wears my clothes, gel type does not.
-wash inside out, cold cycle, about 30 degress celsius. On my washing machine I use either a delicate or wool cycle.
-do not tumble dry. Puy them on a line as straight as posdible and let them air dry still inside out until their dry but the fabric still has a sort of moisture to it. Not wet, but doesn't have to feel sandy dry to the touch.
After trying several methods this is the one that prolongs the life of my jeans and the original color for longer.

>>17469373
>Sport coats

If you've never gotten into them before, either have a friend measure you or paid a tailor 20 bucks to do it. I'd go to the tailor because you're going to probably need to build a relationship with one eventually

Here are the measurements you need in descending importance:

1 Shoulders
2 Chest
3 Waist
4 Sleeves

Shoulders will fuck your fit up and can not be adjusted. Remind yourself of this dozens of times. If your shoulders are 18", you can wear sport coats that are 18-19". Anything too small won't fit, and anything too large will look awful and you can't really cheat around it by adding bulky layers either.

Chest and waist are way easier to work with, if it's a couple inches big they can be taken in. I am cheap and want to avoid the tailor because I am also lazy so I am for sport coats that have a few inches drop between chest and west to emphasize my torso and make me look less like a sack of potatoes. If my chest is 45, I want my waist on the coat to be 41-42. Nothing massive because I'm not in great shape.
Note that this isn't my actual waist, that's a 36.

Sleeves are normally easy to deal with. If they are too long, hem them. If they are a little short don't panic, there's normally an inch built in for adjustment.

Once you have those measurements it's just a matter of patience on eBay. Search for your chest, and then match your measurements from the tailor with the measurements provided by the seller.

>>17469555
>Haha, i like them billowy like that. Its just a full cut, not the wrong size - the neck, armholes, and cuffs fit well.

For the record, that can still be the wrong size. I'm the guy giving sport coat sizing advice, didn't want to go into too much at once and make things more complicated than needed but here's so more info:

My chest is 42", but my neck is 16.5" and it's snug at 16.5. My sleeve length is 36. So if I blindly buy a 16.5x36 dress shirt, the body often billows because my powerful lizard like neck is meant to be with a size 46 to 48 shirt for the chest measurement.

I'm 6'3 and about 215, but even when I was 150 and so much hotter my neck size was still the same. What to do?

1: Buy shirts from retailers like Charles Tyrwhitt that let you choose "cuts". I get a 16.5x36 extra slim. That way my neck isn't choked, but the torso is thinner and so are the sleeves

2: Buy a shirt that fits torso and use collar extenders. It's basically an invisible button with an elastic loop that you attach to your collar button, increases the collar size by an inch. If you're wearing a tie, it's invisible. If you're not wearing a tie, don't button the top button, and then you're fine.

3: Made to measure shirts. This is where I'm gravitating towards now that I get the process and know where to go. This way the shirt will be designed to fit you perfectly

>>17471863
If you're going to blow dry your hair, use a palm sized amount of mousse(golf ball sized amount) on your hair when it's towel dry and only blowdry your hair to about 80% dry/when you start to notice frizz. When styling your hair it's important to have minimal water in it but just enough to where it hasn't set in a style yet. Blow drying sections at a time will help if you don't want to be lazy. Using a larger barrel will give you more volume and less of a curl so you'll have to find the right brush for your hair length. Rotating the brush and blowdrying your hair with a concentrator nozzle in the direction that you're rotating the brush is best for smoothing. I think for Ludwig he blow dries it back and then while it's hot sort of combs his fingers through it to the side for that style he has in that pic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17471551
I struggled with trying to achieve this look for a long time, Anon, but finally found the solution. After bathing, do NOT use a blow dryer. Instead, slightly towel dry your hair and then run a modest amount of Crew fiber (or similar product). Brush your hair completely back, then part your hair (not too close to the center but not too far to the side, either). Now taking a teasing brush, face the ground, and gently tease the bangs area for a few minutes until you can feel your hair *just* starting to transition from wet to dry. Once you're at that point, brush it backwards and try to style it like pic-related. It'll get you closer to that look than if you tried it when your hair's too wet (or dry). Then "lock" the look with some decent hold hairspray.

Just lol at "the point of sagging isn't to show your boxers," yeah man, because you said it it must be true. Some guys sag oversized clothes to hide their boxers, and others don't. In the very late 00s and early 2010s it was popular to wear short shirts and sag below your ass, and guys specifically wore boxer briefs with colorful patterns on them. The point was to draw the attention to their boxer briefs, for the shock value, to mess with the older generation etc. Degenerate af but that was the point. You actually see it today too but it's mostly an African American or ethnic thing in certain metropolitan areas. Guys buy Ethikas, PSD etc boxers with crazy patterns on them and sag in a way that makes the boxer briefs visible, which complements the entire outfit.

The reason sagging is hated on so much is because you have to be attractive, young and confident enough to pull it off. And most people are not all those three things. There's no denying that when done well, it looks sexy as fuck.

posts.sub: Final draft. Short article outlying necklace design.
posts.com:
Yes, indeed there are as many settings as there are shapes. Pavé and channel are what work best for a single row of diamonds, on a base that does not take up that much space. All eventualities, the base alloy needs the strength to hold the diamonds. This is a design; for a necklace; that uses white gold, consisting of gold, platinum and silver. Perhaps, these three elements could be melted together easily and used for jewelry? Indeed, not. It is a complicated process, of yet, unnamed and little known, however results can be achieved which fully satisfy the jeweler's need. Mind you, some benefit from this comes in the form of a higher heat hardening effect. The wire is drawn and wrapped in these 3 shapes: *drawing1
The rings are arranged into a chain. Two larger round ones, followed by one oval and one smaller. *drawing2
Tin, and only tin, is used in place of solder. It is called, eutectic bonding. The touching surfaces of the jump rings are dipped with molten tin. And into the oven at high temperatures for long hours. Gold and tin are eutectic, melting at lower temperatures, allowing diffusion, thus closing the rings.
The necklace envisioned in this design, should be kept as small as possible.
To each his own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17468550
My frame of reference is in canadabucks so bear that in mind.
>Cheap
Arab knockoffs, off-brands and department store shelf goods. Usually from $20-$60. Some deceptively good value in some duplicates if you look around, but be careful not to get scammed.
>Reasonable
Designer house (Dior, Dolce and Gabbana, Versace, Hugo Boss etc.) Eau de Toilettes mostly. Usually around $100 to $140 behind the counter in department stores or at Sephora or your local equivalent, but available much cheaper from reputable online discounters. Always buy from discounters, check the OP. Generally worth the money, will almost always have better performance than their knockoff equivalents.
>Expensive
Niche and upper-rung houses like Creed, Xerjoff, Tom Ford etc. Expect to pay <$300 for a decent sized bottle, or ~$150 for a smaller 30-50ml Eau de Parfum. Usually worth it, but only for something that you've been able to spend some time with in person. Still usually available from discounters.

On every other day I also go to the gym after work, so I can change the fragrance after showering. That means I can wear stuff my gf doesn't like to work and change for bed and so on.
SOTD Chanel Egoiste, which technically lasts too long, since it will still perform when I hit the gym this evening. After that Marbert Man Classic for bed, because my gf isn't staying over.

>>17468550
Entirely based on the person. I consider stuff above 2€/mL basically overpriced (calculated for a 100 mL bottle, usually). There's so much good stuff below that. I try to buy designers at around 0.50€/mL (or less), because they are often on sale for that price. I'll spend up to 1€/mL for the higher quality designers and anything between 1€ and 2€/mL for niche. There are also some fragrances which are within that price range and which I consider interesting, but not interesting enough to buy. I currently have this problem with B683, which smells really good to me, but not 190€/100mL good. For that, it is a tiny bit lacking.
Prices like Roja and Creed ask for are entirely bullshit to me and they won't get my money, simple as. I can find stuff I like better for less money.

>>17468564
Chanel Platinum Egoiste. Not only is Armaf not a good clone house, copying Chanel fragrances is usually really hard as well.

>>17469649
Opium pour homme

it's getting hard to find and price has gone up but it's so worth it still even for $80. Not officially discontinued I guess just not in high circulation.
It's zesty and juicy opening with black current and star anise and dries down to the best vanilla any fragrance has. On the way it gets a kind of bubblegummy smell in the background as the vanilla starts to take over. It's the one scent that gives me a little endorphin rush when I first try it after going a while without it.

Only downside is longevity. It lasts about 3 hours on me before becoming unnoticeable but projection is good for most of that time. But pretty much everything is short lived on my skin.

There are some arabic dupes around i want to try too, but haven't come across them yet. For me, the newer CW only performs well on cold days and loses its resemblance when its getting hot. It's unfortuneatly like a pixelated photo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17470086
On the same trip my man, been wondering about vintage CW for almost a decade but only recently have i ventured in the world of fragrances because my last teenage frag ended (Boss Element) and i have no signature again, CW being my first and most enduring scent through childhood and teenage years.
I have tested GIT in expensive, perhaps ill-stored decanters and it smells nice but too grassy and no oakmoss/dampness scent, Tres Nuit will be my first buy since i started learning about frags (December last year) and that Floris JF i read yesterday that it's expensive, no good performance and shipping costs a lot but seems to be a fruitier GIT.
Other than that i read about Aventure Knight from Haramain but they say it's too oriental and strong for its own good, Chez Bond no. 9 seems to be similar to CW in the aperture but the drydown is supposedly creamier/floral rather than woody.

>but it is much more floral
How so? iris, violet?
Also about Aspen because it is the same bottle and made by Coty i always discarded it but your words have interested me, what i truly miss from CW is not the high-quality non-stringent calone but the greeness/oakmoss aspect of its base note, which is totally absent in Coty CW.
>It's unfortuneatly like a pixelated photo.
For me it's almost a different frag, it's very sharp in the aperture and dries down to a salty old lemon while vintage opened with pleasant soft calone and lemon with a strong hint of greeness and dried down to the smell of humid cedar with a bit of tobacco. Fresh vintage CW was something else, much more complex than today and it's a shame few newcomers know exactly why it was so rampantly popular to the point of surpassing Drakkar Noir.

>>17470876
It's easier to describe a fragrance by vibe than by actual notes. Whenever I pass by a juniper tree, I am reminded that the smell of "juniper" in fragrances rarely matches real juniper. Most lavender doesn't smell like lavender yet every fougere claims to have it (Invasion Barbare is the only stuff that smells like actual lavender mixed with lavender oil to me). It's hard to describe chemicals which by now might even be entirely "made up" with no natural counterpart. My SOTD is Eau des Baux - a spicy opening, but is it cardamom and pink pepper? Not really. It's spicy and a bit peppery, for sure, but that's it. Is the drydown cypress and incense? Not really. Vanilla and tonka bean? There's certainly vanilla, but tonka bean feels like one of those "random" notes like "amber" by now, even though it technically means coumarin. I could say it smells like Christmas, but so does Egoiste or SWY Absolutely, just in a different way. It's just an easy way to describe something, except for maybe civet since that's an actual note.

>>17467312
no. roughout is done to make the boot more resistant to scuffs and abrasion. The fibers on the outside will simply brush back into position.
The downside is that it's harder to get oil out, and because it's the soft fibers out, it's easier for something pointy to begin puncturing the boot, whereas the smooth-out boots, that same pointy bit might just slide off and leave a nasty scratch.

There is no perfect boot, but I love roughout anyway.

posts.com:
Here's something you don't see often. These boots were made between 1988 and 1993 by a now defunct American shoe making company called Stuart McGuire. Found this pair on eBay, all I've done to them is clean, condition and polish.
To be blunt, Stuart McGuire was (for the time) a very middle of the road shoe company, absolutely nothing special. That's what makes these boots surprising, they are pretty much equal in quality to modern offerings from much higher level/established bootmakers.

The leather is thick but supple, feels great on my feet. I'm shocked at how comfortable these boots are on, there's no problem spots. Arch support is superb, the last is a little wide but that works for me. I'm between a 12D and 12E on Brannock, these are a 12D and I can last them nice and tight without feeling like they are too narrow. Length wise is perfect, and the height is good so I can wiggle my toes a little but not feel loose. Heel is fantastic, no slipping. Soles are vibram, some of the stitching is frayed but otherwise the sole is in great shape, with how infrequently I'll wear this it will be years before I'll have to take them to a cobbler. I do need to replace the laces, these are the original and they're a little dingy.

The only downside to these boots are the number of eyelets. 10 eyelets, no speed hooks. I've never seen this system before, I have to thread the lace through these short brass tubes. It doesn't take too long and it feels very supportive once it's laced up.
I'm not a boot expert by any means. I've got Allen Edmonds, Chippewa 1939,Grant Stone, Red Wing, Thorogood, Dan Post, a couple of pair of vintage Florsheim as well. If this boot was handed to me in brand new condition today I'd have zero issue paying current Red Wing prices for it. Really happy I stumbled across it.
Here's some more pics of the boots

https://imgur.com/a/y8pScKr

Based. I used to feel insulted by watches that cost more than $100 but had the same technology as a $20 Timex, but having had the quartz version of a certain Tissot that has been recently very popular, I realise it was Timex that sucked, not quartz movements.
